sp.p: Why then you must not ask such School-boyes questions. (But your Carkase, Sirrah, shall pay for this.)—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You seem not to understand the Terms, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, I know there are five of 'em; do not I know your Michaelmas, your Hillary, your Easter, your Trinity, and your Long Vacation term, Sir?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I do not understand a word of this Jargon.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It may be not, Sir; I believe the terms are not the same in Spain they are in England.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Did one ever hear so impudent an ignorance?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: The terms of Art are the same every where.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Tell me that! you are an old man, and they are alter'd since you studied them.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: That may be I must confess; however if you please to discourse something of the Art to me, you shall find me an apt Scholar.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir,—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry a business of importance calls me hence; but I'll wait on you some other time, to discourse more at large of Astrologie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Is your business very pressing?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: It is, I assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am very sorry, for I should have instructed you in such rare secrets; I have no fault, but that I am too communicative.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I'll dispatch my business, and return immediately; come away Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A Devil on's learning; he had brought me to my last legs; I was fighting as low as ever was Squire Widdrington.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Who would have suspected it from that wicked Elder?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Suspected it? why 'twas palpable from his very Physnomy; he looks like Haly, and the spirit Fircu in the Fortune-book.

sp.speaker: Widl.
sp.p: How now Bellamy, in wrath, prethee, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The story is too long to tell you; but this Rogue here has made me pass for an errant Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: If I had not, I am sure he must have past for an errant Mad-man; he had discover'd, in a rage, all that Beatrix had confess'd to me concerning her Mistresse's love; and I had no other way to bring him off, but to say he knew it by the Planets.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And art thou such an Oph to be vext at this? as the adventure may be manag'd it may make the most pleasant one in all the Carnival.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Death! I shall have all Madrid about me within these two dayes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, all Spain, i'faith, as fast as I can divulge thee: not a Ship shall pass out from any Port, but shall ask thee for a wind; thou shalt have all the trade of Lapland within a Month.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And do you think it reasonable for me to stand defendant to all the impertinent questions that the Town can ask me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Thou shalt do't boy: pox on thee, thou dost not know thine own happiness; thou wilt have the Ladies come to thee; and if thou dost not sit them with fortunes, thou art bewitch'd.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis the easiest thing in Nature; you need but speak doubtfully, or keep your self in general terms, and for the most part tell good rather than bad fortune.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
And if at any time thou ventur'st at particulars, have an evasion ready like Lilly; as thus, it will infallibly happen if our sins hinder not. I would undertake with one of his Almanacks to give very good content to all Christendom, and
what good luck fell not out in one Kingdom, should in another.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: The pleasure on't will be to see how all his Customers will contribute to their own deceiving; and verily believe he told them that, which they told him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Umh! now I begin to taste it; I am like the drunken Tinker in the Play, a great Prince, and never knew it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A great Prince, a great Turk; we shall have thee within these two dayes, do grace to the Ladies by throwing out a handkerchief; ' lif, I could feast upon thy fragments.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If the women come you shall be sure to help me to undergo the burden; for though you make me an Astronomer I am no Atlas, to bear all upon my back. But who are these?
sp.stage: Enter Musicians with disguises; and some in their hands.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You know the men if their Masquing habits were off; they are the Musick of our Embassadors Retinue: my project is to give our Mistresses a Serenade; this being the last Evening of the Carnival; and to prevent discovery here are disguises for us too.——

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; come Maskall help on with 'em, while they tune their Instruments.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Strike up Gentlemen; we'll entertain 'em with a song al' Angloise, pray be ready with your Chorus.

lg.l: After the pangs of a desperate Lover,
When day and night I have sigh'd all in vain,
Ah what a pleasure it is to discover
In her eyes pity, who causes my pain!
When with unkindness our love at a stand is,
And both have punish'd our selves with the pain,
Ah what a pleasure the touch of her hand is,
Ah what a pleasure to press it again!
When the denyal comes fainter and fainter,,
And her eyes give what her tongue does deny,
Ah what a trembling I feel when I venture,
Ah what a trembling does usher my joy!
When, with a Sigh, she accords me the blessing,
And her eyes twinkle 'twixt pleasure and pain;
Ah what a joy 'tis beyond all expressing,
Ah what a joy to hear, shall we again!

div.stage: Jacinta throws down her handkerchief with a Favour ty'd to it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ill Musicians must be rewarded: there, Cavalier, 'tis to buy your silence.——

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By this light, which at present is scarce an oath, an handkerchief and a favour.
sp.stage: Musick and Guittars tuning on the other side of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hark, Wildblood, do you hear; there's more melody; on my life some Spaniards have taken up this Post for the same design.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I'll be with their Cats-guts immediately.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Prethee be patient; we shall lose the sport else.
sp.stage: Don Lopez and Don Melchor disguis'd, with Servants, and Musicians on the other side.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis some Rival of yours or mine, Bellamy: for he addresses to this window.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Damn him, let's fall on then.
sp.stage: The two Spaniards and the English fight: the Spaniards are beaten off the Stage; the Musicians on both sides and Servants fall confusedly one over the other. They all get off, only Maskal remains upon the ground.

sp.speaker: Mask. rising.
sp.p:
So, all's past, and I am safe: a pox on these fighting Masters of mine, to bring me into this danger with
their valours and magnanimities. When I go a Serenading again with 'em, I'll give 'em leave to make Fiddle-strings of my small-guts.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: 'Tis Don Lopez by his voice.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: The same; and by yours you should belong to my two English Ghests. Did you hear no tumult hereabouts?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: I heard a clashing of swords, and men a fighting

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I had my share in't; but how came you here:

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I came hither by my Masters order to see if you were in any danger.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: But how could he imagine I was in any?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: 'Tis all one for that, Sir, he knew it, by— Heaven, what was I agoing to say, I had like to have disover'd all!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I find there is some secret in't; and you dare not trust me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: If you will swear on your honor to be very secret, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: As I am a Cavalier, and by my Beard, I will.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Then, in few words, he knew it by Astrologie, or Magick.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: You amaze me! Is he conversant in the occult Sciences?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Most profoundly.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: I alwayes thought him an extraordinary person; but I could never imagine his head lay that way.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: He shew'd me yesterday in a glass a Ladies Maid at London, whom I well knew; and with whom I us'd to converse on a Pallet in a drawing-room, while he was paying his devotions to her Lady in the Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Lord, what a treasure for a State were here! and how much might we save by this man, in Forreign Intelligence!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And just now he shew'd me how you were assaulted in the dark by Foreigners.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Could you guess what Countrymen?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: I imagin'd them to be Italians.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Not unlikely; for they play'd most furiously at our back-sides.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I will return to my Master with the good news of your safety; but once again be secret; or disclose it to none but friends.—— So, there's one Woodcock more in the Springe.—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Yes, I will be very secret; for I will tell it only to one person; but she is a woman. I will to Aurelia, and acquaint her with the skill of this rare Artist: she is curious as all women are; and, 'tis probable, will desire to look into the Glass to see Don Melchor, whom she believes absent. So that by this means, without breaking my oath to him, he will be discover'd to be in Town. Then his intrigue with Theodosia will come to light too, for which Aurelia will, I hope, discard him, and receive me. I will about it instantly:
sp.l: Success, in love, on diligence depends;
No lazie Lover e're attain'd his ends.

div.head: ACT. III.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: THen, they were certainly Don Lopez and Don Mel-Melchor with whom we fought!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And when you met Lopez he swallow'd all you told him?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: As greedily, as if it had been a new Saints miracle.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I see 'twill spread.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And the fame of it will be of use to you in your next amour: for the women you know run mad after Fortune-tellers and Preachers.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But for all my bragging this amour is not yet worn off. I find constancy, and once a night come naturally upon a man towards thirty: only we set a face on't; and call our selves unconstant for our reputation.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: But, What say the Starrs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They move faster than you imagine; for I have got me an Argol, and an English-Almanack; by help of which in one half-hour I have learnt to Cant with an indifferent good grace: Conjunction, Opposition, Trine, Square and Sextile, are now no longer Bug-bears to me, I thank my Starrs for't.
— Monsieur Wildblood, in good time! What, you have been taking pains too, to divulge my Tallent?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: So successfully, that shortly there will be no talk in Town but of you onely: another Miracle or two, and a sharp Sword, and you stand fair for a New Prophet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But where did you begin to blow the Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: In the Gaming-house: where I found most of the Town-wits; the Prose-wits playing, and the Verse-wits cooking.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All sorts of Gamesters are so Superstitious, that I need not doubt of my reception there.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: From thence I went to the latter end of a Comedy, and there whisper'd it to the next Man I knew who had a Woman by him.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Nay, then it went like a Train of Powder, if once they had it by the end.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Like a Squib upon a Line, i'faith, it ran through one row, and came back upon me in the next: at my going out I met a knot of Spaniards, who were formally listening to one who was relating it: but he told the Story so ridiculously, with his Marginal Notes upon it, that I was forc'd to contradict him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Twas discreetly done.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I, for you, but not for me: What, sayes he, must such Boracho's as you, take upon you to villifie a Man of Science? I tell you, he's of my intimate Acquaintance, and I have known him long, for a prodigious person— When I saw my Don so fierce, I thought it not wisdom to quarrel for so slight a matter as you Reputation, and so withdrew.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A pox of your success! now shall I have my Chamber besieg'd to morrow morning: there will be no stiring out for me; but I must be fain to take up their Questions in a cleft-Cane, or a Begging-box, as they do Charity in Prisons.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot help what your Learning has brought you to: Go in and study; I foresee you will have but few Holy-dayes: in the mean time I'll not fail to give the World an account of your indowments. Fare-well: I'll to the Gaming house.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: O, Sir, here is the rarest adventure, and which is more, come home to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: A fair Lady and her Woman, wait in the outer Room to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But how know you she is fair?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Her Woman pluck'd up her Vaile when she spake to me; so that having seen her this evening, I know her Mistress to be Donna Aurelia, Cousin to your Mistress Theodosia, and who lodges in the same House with her: she wants a Starr or two I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My whole Constellation is at her service: but what is she for a Woman?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Fair enough, as Beatrix has told me; but sufficiently impertinent. She is one of those Ladies who make ten Visits in an afternoon; and entertain her they see, with speaking ill of the last from whom they parted: in few words, she is one of the greatest Coquette's in Madrid: and to show she is one, she cannot speak ten words without some affected phrase that is in fashion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For my part I can suffer any impertinence from a woman, provided she be handsome: my business is with her Beauty, not with her Morals: let her Confessor look to them.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: I wonder what she has to say to you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I know not; but I sweat for fear I should be gravell'd.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Venture out of your depth, and plunge boldly Sir; I warrant you will swimm.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do not leave me I charge you; but when I look mournfully upon you help me out.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Here they are already.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How am I drest to night, Camilla? is nothing disorder'd in my head?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not the least hair, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: No? let me see: give me the Counsellor of the Graces.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: The Counsellor of the Graces, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My Glass I mean: what will you never be so spiritual as to understand refin'd language?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Madam!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Madam me no Madam, but learn to retrench your words; and say Mam; as yes Mam, and no Mam, as other Ladies Women do. Madam! 'tis a year in pronouncing.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yet again ignorance: par-don Madam, fie fie, what a superfluity is there, and how much sweeter the Cadence is, parn me Mam! and for your Ladyship, your Laship— Out upon't, what a furious indigence of Ribands is here upon my head! This dress is a Libel to my beauty; a meer Lampoon. Would any one that had the least revenue of common sense have done this?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Mam the Cavalier approaches your Laship.

sp.speaker: Bell. to Mask.
sp.p: Maskall, pump the woman; and see if you can discover any thing to save my credit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Out upon it; now I should speak I want assurance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam, I was told you meant to honor me with your Commands.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I believe, Sir, you wonder at my confidence in this visit: but I may be excus'd for waving a little modesty to know the only person of the Age.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I wish my skill were more to serve you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, you are an unfit judge of your own merits: for my own part I confess I have a furious inclination for the occult Sciences; but at present 'tis my misfortune——

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But why that sigh, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You might spare me the shame of telling you; sioce I am sure you can divine my thoughts: I will therefore tell you nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What the Devil will become of me now!—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You may give me an Essay of your Science, by declaring to me the secret of my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If I know your thoughts, Madam, 'tis in vain for you to disguise them to me: therefore as you tender your own satisfaction lay them open without bashfulness.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I beseech you let us pass over that chapter; for I am shamefac'd to the last point: Since therefore I cannot put off my modesty, succour it, and tell me what I think.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, that bashfulness must be laid aside: not but that I know your business perfectly; and will if you please unfold it to you all, immediately.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Favour me so far, I beseech you, Sir; for I furiously desire it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But then I must call up before you a most dreadful Spirit, with head upon head, and horns upon horns: therefore consider how you can endure it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This is furiously furious; but rather than fail of my expectances, I'll try my assurance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, then, I find you will force me to this unlawful, and abominable act of Conjuration: remember the sin is yours too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I espouse the crime also.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I see when a woman has a mind to't, she'll never boggle at a sin. Pox on her, what shall I do?— Well, I'll tell you your thoughts, Madam; but after that expect no farther service from me; for 'tis your confidence must make my Art succesful:— Well, you are obstinate, then; I must tell you your thoughts?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I am content to pass over that chapter rather than be depriv'd of your assistance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; what need these circumstances between us two? Confess freely, is not love your business?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: You have touch'd me to the quick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: La you there; you see I knew it; nay, I'll tell you more, 'tis a man you love.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: O prodigious Science! I confess I love a man most furiously, to the last point, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now proceed Lady, your way is open; I am resolv'd I'll not tell you a word farther.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, then, since I must acquaint you with what you know much better than my self; I will tell you I lov'd a Cavalier, who was noble, young, and handsome; this Gentleman is since gone for Flanders; now whether he has preserv'd his passion inviolate or not, is that which causes my inquietude.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Trouble not your self, Madam; he's as constant as a Romance Heros.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Sir, your good news has ravish'd most furiously; but that I may have a confirmation of it, I beg only, that you would lay your commands upon his Genius, or Idea, to appear to me this night, that I may have my sentence from his mouth. This, Sir, I know is a slight effect of your Science, and yet will infinitely oblige me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What the Devil does she call a slight effect! [aside] Why Lady, do you consider what you say? you desire me to shew you a man whom your self confess to be in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To view him in a glass is nothing, I would speak with him in person, I mean his Idea, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I but Madam, there is a vast sea betwixt us and Flanders; and water is an enemy to Conjuration: A witches horse you know, when he enters into water, returns into a bottle of hay again.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, Sir, I am not so ill a Geographer, or to speak more properly, a Chorographer, as not to know there is a passage by land from hence to Flanders.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's true, Madam, but Magick works in a direct line. Why should you think the Devil such an Ass to goe about? 'gad he'll not stir a step out of his road for you or any man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, for a Lady, Sir; I hope he's a person that wants not that civility for a Lady: especially a spirit that has the honor to belong to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For that matter he's your Servant, Madam; but his education has been in the fire, and he's naturally an enemy to water I assure you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I beg his pardon for forgetting his Antipathy; but it imports not much, Sir; for I have lately receiv'd a letter from my Servant, that he is yet in Spain; and stays for a wind in St. Sebastians.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I am lost past all redemption.— Maskall— must you be smickering after Wenches while I am in calamity?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: It must be he, I'll venture on't. [aside] Alas Sir, I was complaining to my self of the condition of poor Don Melchor, who you know is windbound at St. Sebastians.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why you impudent Villain, must you offer to name him publickly, when I have taken so much care to conceal him all this while?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Mitigate your displeasure I beseech you; and without making farther testimony of it, gratifie my expectances.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Madam, since the Sea hinders not, you shall have your desire. Look upon me with a fix'd eye— so— or a little more amorously if you please.— Good. Now favour me with your hand.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Is it absolutely necessary you should press my hand thus?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Furiously necessary, I assure you, Madam; for now I take possession of it in the name of the Idea of Don Melchor. Now, Madam, I am farther to desire of you, to write a Note to his Genius, wherein you desire him to appear, and this, we Men of Art, call a Compact with the Idea's.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I tremble furiously.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Give me your hand, I'll guide it.

sp.speaker: Mask. to Cam.
sp.p: Now, Lady mine, what think you of my Master?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I think I would not serve him for the world: nay, if he can know our thoughts by looking on us, we women are hypocrites to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: He can do that and more; for by casting his eyes but once upon them, he knows whether they are Maids, better than a whole Jury of Midwives.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Now Heaven defend me from him.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: He has a certain small Familiar which he carries still about him, that never fails to make discovery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: See, they have done writing; not a word more, for fear he knows my voice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One thing I had forgot, Madam, you must subscribe your name to't.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: There 'tis; farewell Cavalier, keep your promise, for I expect it furiously.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If he sees me I am undone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cam. starts and schreeks.
sp.l: Ah he has found me; I am ruin'd!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You hide your face in vain; for I see into your heart.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Then, sweet Sir, have pity on my srailty; for if my Lady has the least inkling of what we did last night, the poor Coachman will be turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Well, Sir, how like you your New Profession?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Would I were well quit on't; I sweat all over.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But what faint-hearted Devils yours are that will not go by water? Are they all Lancashire Devils, of the brood of Tybert and Grimalkin, that they dare not wet their feet?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mine are honest land Devils, good plain foot Posts, that beat upon the hoof for me: but to save their labour, here take this, and in some disguise deliver it to Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I'll serve it upon him within this hour, when he sallyes out to his assignation with Theodosia: 'tis but counterfeiting my voice a little; for he cannot know me in the dark. But let me see, what are the words?

Don Melchor, if the Magique of love have any power upon your spirit, I conjure you to appear this night before me: you may guess the greatness of my passion, since it has forc'd me to have recourse to Art: but no shape which resembles you can fright
Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, I am glad there's one point gain'd; for by this means he will be hindred to night from entertaining Theodosia.— Pox on him, is he here again?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Cavalier Ingles I have been seeking you: I have a Present in my Pocket for you; read it by your Art and take it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That I could do easily;— but to shew you I am generous, I'll none of your Present; do you think I am mercenary?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know you will say now 'tis some Astrological question, and so 'tis perhaps.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I, 'tis the Devil of a question without dispute.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No 'tis within dispute: 'tis a certain difficulty in the Art; a Problem which you and I will discuss, with the arguments on both sides,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: At this time I am not problematically given; I have a humour of complaisance upon me, and will contradict no man.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: We'll but discuss a little.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By your favour I'll not discusse; for I see by the Stars that if I Dispute to day, I am infallibly threatned to be thought ignorant all my life after.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Well, then, we'll but cast an eye together, upon my eldest Daughters Nativity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nativity!—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say now, that there wants the Table of Direction for the five Hylegiacalls; the Ascendant, Medium Coeli, Sun, Moon, and Sors: but we'll take it as it is.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Never tell me that, Sir—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I know what you would say again, Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis well you do, for I'll besworn I do not—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You would say, Sir—.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I say, Sir, there is no doing without the Sun and Moon, and all that, Sir. And so you may make use of your Paper for your occasions. Come to a man of Art without [tears it. the Sun and Moon, and all that, Sir—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p:
'Tis no matter; this shall break no squares betwixt us: [Gathers up the Torne Papers.
I know what you would say now, that Men of parts are alwayes cholerick; I know it by my self, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Don Alonzo in my house! this is a most happy opportunity to put my other design in execution; for if I can perswade him to bestow his Daughter on Don Melchor, I shall serve my Friend, though against his will: and, when Aurelia sees she cannot be his, perhaps she will accept my Love.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, 'tis all piec'd right, both top, sides and bottom; for, look you, Sir, here was Aldeboran, and there Cor Scorpii—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Don Alonzo, I am happy to see you under my Roof: and shall take it—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, Sir, that though I am your neighbour, this is the first time I have been here. [to Bellamy— But, come, Sir, by Don Lopez his permission let us return to our Nativity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Would thou wert there, in thy Mother's Belly again.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: But Sennor— to Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: It needs not Sennor; I'll suppose your Compliment; you would say that your house and all things in it are at my service: but let us proceed without his interruption.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: By no means, Sir; this Cavalier is come on purpose to perform the civilities of his house to you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: But, good Sir—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I know what you would say, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: No matter, let him go, Sir; I have long desir'd this opportunity to move a Sute to you in the behalf of a Friend of mine: if you please to allow me the hearing of it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: He is a person of worth and vertue, and is infinitely ambitious of the honour—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Of being known to me; I understand you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: If you will please to favour me with your patience, which I beg of you a second time.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am dumb, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This Cavalier of whom I was speaking, is in Love—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Satisfie your self, Sir, I'll not interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Sir, I am satisfied of your promise.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If I speak one Syllable more the Devil take me: speak when you please.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I am going, Sir;

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You need not speak twice to me to be silent: though I take it somewhat ill of you to be tutor'd—

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This eternal old Man will make me mad.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Why when do you begin, Sir? How long must a man wait for you? pray make an end of what you have to say quickly, that I may speak in my turn too.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: This Cavalier is in Love—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You told me that before, Sir; Do you speak Oracles that you require this strict attention? either let me share the talk with you or I am gone.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I am almost mad to tell you, and you will not suffer me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Will you never have done, Sir; I must tell you, Sir, you have tatled long enough; and 'tis now good Manners to hear me speak. Here's a Torrent of words indeed; a very impetus dicendi, Will you never have done?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: I will be heard in spight of you.
sp.stage: This next Speech of Lopez, and the next of Alonzo's, with both their Replies, are to be spoken at one time; both raising their voices by little and little, till they baul, and come up close to shoulder one another.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: There's one Don Melchor de Guzman, a Friend and Acquaintance of mine, that is desperately in Love with your eldest Daughter Donna Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: 'Tis the sentence of a Philosopher, Loquere ut te videam; Speak that I may know thee; now if you take away the power of speaking from me—
sp.stage: Both pause a little; then speak together again.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p:
I'll try the Language of the Law; sure the Devil cannot
out-talke that Gibberish— For this Don Melchor of Madrid aforesaid, as premised, I request, move, and supplicate, that you would give, bestow, Marry, and give in Mariage, this your Daughter aforesaid, to the Cavalier aforesaid— not yet, thou Devil of a Man thou shalt be silent—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: At the fume time with Lopez his last speech, and after Lopez is runout Oh, how I hate, abominate, detest and abhor, these perpetual Talkers, Disputants, Controverters, and Duellers of the Tongue! But, on the other side, if it be not permitted to prudent men to speak their minds, appositely, and to the purpose ' and in few words— If, I say, the prudent must be Tongue-ty'd; then let Great Nature be destroy'd; let the order of all things be turn'd topsy-turvy; let the Goose devour the Fox; let the Infants preach to their Great-Grandsires; let the tender Lamb pursue the Woolfe, and the Sick prescribe to the Physician. Let Fishes live upon dry-land, and the Beasts of the Earth inhabit in the Water.— Let the fearful Hare—
sp.stage: Enter Lopez with a Bell, and rings it in his ears.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Help, help, murder, murder, murder. Exit Alonzo running.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: There was no way but this to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there are some Women without in Masquerade; and, I believe, persons of Quality, who are come to Play here.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: Bring 'em in with all respect.
sp.stage: Enter again the Servant, after him Jacinta, Beatrix, and other Ladies and Gentlemen; all Masqued.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Cavaliers, and Ladies, you are welcome: I wish I had more company to entertain you:— Oh, here comes one sooner then I expected.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: I have swept your Gaming-house, i'faith, Ecce signunt.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Well, here's more to be had of these Ladies, if it be your fortune.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The first Stakes I would play for, should be their Vailes, and Visor Masques.

sp.speaker: Jac. to Beat.
sp.l: Do you think he will not know us?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: If you keep your Design of passing for an African.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well, now I shall make an absolute trial of him; for, being thus incognita, I shall discover if he make Love to any of you. As for the Gallantry of his Serenade, we will not be indebted to him, for we will make him another with our Guittars.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I'll whisper your intention to the Servant, who shall deliver it to Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: Serv. to Lopez.
sp.p: Sir, the Ladies have commanded me to tell you, that they are willing, before they Play, to present you with a Dance; and to give you an Essay of their Guittars.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.l: They much honor me.

div.stage: After the Dance the Cavaliers take the Ladies and Court them. Wildblood takes Jacinta;

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: While you have been Singing, Lady, I have been Praying: I mean, that your Face and Wit may not prove equal to your Dancing; for, if they be, there's a heart gone astray to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If you pray against me before you have seen me, you'll curse me when you have look'd on me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I believe I shall have cause to do so, if your Beauty be as killing as I imagine it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I have been flatter'd in my own Country, with an opinion of a little handsomness; but, how it will pass in Spain is a question.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why Madam, Are you not of Spain?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, Sir, of Marocco: I onely came hither to see some of my Relations who are setled here, and turn'd Christians, since the expulsion of my Countrymen the Moors.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Are you then a Mahometan?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A Musullman at your service.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Musullwoman say you? I protest by your voice I should have taken you for a Christian Lady of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: It seems you are in love then: if so, I have done with you. I dare not invade the Dominions of another Lady; especially in a Country where my Ancestors have been so unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Some little liking I might have, but that was onely a morning-dew, 'tis drawn up by the Sun-shine of your Beauty: I find your African-Cupid is a much surer Archer then ours of Europe. Yet would I could see you; one look would secure your victory.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll reserve my Face to gratifie your imagination with it, make what head you please, and set it on my Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, Madam, an eye, a nose, or a lip shall break no squares: the Face is but a spans breadth of beauty; and where there is so much besides, I'll never stand with you for that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But, in earnest, Do you love me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I, by Alha do I, most extreamly: you have Wit in abundance, you Dance to a Miracle, you Sing like an Angel, and I believe you look like a Cherubim.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And can you be constant to me?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: By Mahomet, can I.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You Swear like a Turk, Sir; but, take heed: for our Prophet is a severe punisher of Promise-breakers.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Your Prophet's a Cavalier; I honour your Prophet and his Law, for providing so well for us Lovers in the
other World, Black Eyes, and Fresh-Maidenheads every day; go thy way little Mahomet, i'faith thou shalt have my good word. But, by his favour Lady, give me leave to tell you, that we of the Uncircumcised, in a civil way, as Lovers, have somewhat the advantage of your Musullman.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The Company are rejoyn'd, and set to play; we must go to 'em: Adieu, and when you have a thought to throw away, bestow it on your Servant Fatyma.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: This Lady Fatyma pleases me most infinitely: now am I got among the Hamets, the Zegrys, and the Bencerrages. Hey, What work will the Wildbloods make among the Cids and the Bens of the Arabians!

sp.speaker: Beat. to Jac.
sp.l: False, or true Madam?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: False as Hell; but by Heaven I'll fit him for't: Have you the high-running Dice about you?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I got them on purpose, Madam.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You shall see me win all their Mony; and when I have done, I'll return in my own person, and ask him for the money which he promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: 'Twill put him upon a streight to be so surpriz'd: but, let us to the Table; the Company stayes for us.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: What is the Ladies Game, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Most commonly they use Raffle. That is, to throw with three Dice, till Duplets and a chance be thrown; and the highest Duplets wins except you throw In and In, which is call'd Raffle; and that wins all.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I understand it: Come, Lady, 'tis no matter what I lose; the greatest stake, my heart, is gone already
sp.stage: To Jacinta. They play: and the rest by couples.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: So, I have a good chance, two quaters and a sice.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Two sixes and a trey wins it.— sweeps the money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No matter; I'll try my fortune once again: what have I here two sixes and a quater?— an hundred Pistols on that throw.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I take you, Sir.— Beatrix the high running Dice.—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Here Madam.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Three fives: I have won you Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I, the pox take me for't, you have won me: it would never have vex'd me to have lost my money to a Christian; but to a Pagan, an Infidel.—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Pray, Sir, leave off while you have some money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pox of this Lady Fatyma! Raffle thrice together, I am out of patience.

sp.speaker: Mask. to him.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you if you will lose, to lose en Cavalier.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Tol de ra, tol de ra— pox and curse— tol de ra, &c. What the Devil did I mean to play with this Brunet of Afrique?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Will you be gone already Ladies?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: You have won our money; but however we are acknowledging to you for the honor of your company.
sp.stage: Jacinta makes a sign of farewel to Wildblood.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Farewell Lady Fatyma.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Wild. and Mask.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: All the company took notice of your concernment.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; I do not love to fret inwardly, as your silent losers do, and in the mean time be ready to choak for want of vent.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Pray consider your condition a little; a younger Brother in a foreign Country, living at a high rate, your money lost, and without hope of a supply. Now curse if you think good.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, now I will laugh at my self most unmercifully: for my condition is so ridiculous that 'tis past cursing. The pleasantest part of the adventure is, that I have promis'd 300 pistols to Jacinta: but there is no remedy, they are now fair Fatyma's.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Fatyma!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I, I, a certain African Lady of my acquaintance whom you know not.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: But who is here, Sir!
sp.stage: Enter Jacinta and Beatrix in their own shapes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, what happy star has conducted you hither to night! A thousand Devils of this fortune!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I was told you had Ladies here and fiddles; so I came partly for the divertisement, and partly out of jealousie.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Jealousie! why sure you do not think me a Pagan, an Infidel? But the company's broke up you see. Am I to wait upon you home, or will you be so kind to take a hard lodging with me to night?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You shall have the honor to lead me to my Father's.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No more words then, let's away to prevent discovery.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: For my part I think he has a mind to be rid of you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No: but if your Lady should want sleep, 'twould spoil the lustre of her eyes to morrow. There were a Conquest lost.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am a peaceable Princess, and content with my own; I mean your heart, and purse; for the truth is, I have lost my money to night in Masquerade, and am come to claim your promise of supplying me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You make me happy by commanding me: to morrow morning my servant shall wait upon you with 300 pistols.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: But I left my company with promise to return to play.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Play on tick, and lose the Indies, I'll discharge it all to morrow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: To night, if you'll oblige me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Maskall, go and bring me 300 pistols immediately.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Are you mad Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do you expostulate you rascall! how he stares; I'll be hang'd if he have not lost my gold at play: if you have, confess you had best, and perhaps I'll pardon you; but if you do not confess I'll have no mercy: did you lose it?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis not for me to dispute with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Why then let me tell you, you did lose it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I, as sure as e're he had it, I dare swear for him: but commend to you for a kind Master, that can let your Servant play off 300 pistols, without the least sign of anger to him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign he has a greater banck in store to comfort him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I must confess I have more then I will speak of at this time; but till you have given me satisfaction—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Satisfaction; why are you offended, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Heaven! that you should not perceive it in me: I tell you I am mortally offended with you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sure 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You have done nothing I warrant to make a man jealous: going out a gaming in Masquerade, at unseasonable hours, and losing your money, at play; that loss above all provokes me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I believe you; because she comes to you for more.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Is this the quarrel? I'll clear it immediately.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible you should clear it; I'll stop my ears if you but offer it. There's no satisfaction in the point.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You'll hear me?—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To do this in the beginning of an amour, and to a jealous servant as I am; had I all the wealth of Peru, I would not let go one Maravedis to you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: To this I answer—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Answer nothing, for it will but inflame the quarrel betwixt us: I must come to my self by little and little; and when I am ready for satisfaction I will take it: but at present it is not for my honor to be friends.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Pray let us neighbour Princes interpose a little.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: When I have conquer'd, you may interpose; but at present the mediation of all Christendome would be fruitless.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Though Christendome can do nothing with you, yet I hope an African may prevail. Let me beg you for the sake of the Lady Fatyma.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I begin to suspect that Lady Fatyma is no better than she should be. If she be turn'd Christian again I am undone.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: By Alha I am afraid on't too: By Mahomet I am.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, well, Madam, any man may be overtaken with an oath; but I never meant to perform it with her: you know no oathes are to be kept with Infidels. But———

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, the love you made was certainly a design of charitie you had to reconcile the two Religions. There's scarce such another man in Europe to be sent Apostle to convert the Moor Ladies.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith I would rather widen their breaches then make 'em up.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I see there's no hope of a reconcilement with you; and therefore I give it o're as desperate.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You have gain'd your point, you have my money; and I was only angry because I did not know 'twas you who had it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: This will not serve your turn, Sir; what I have got I have conquer'd from you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Indeed you use me like one that's conquer'd; for you have plunder'd me of all I had.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I only difarm'd you for fear you should rebell again; for if you had the sinews of warr I am sure you would be flying out.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Dare but to stay without a new Servant till I am flush again, and I will love you, and treat you, and present you at that unreasonable rate; that I will make you an example to all unbelieving Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well, I will trie you once more; but you must make haste then, that we may be within our time; methinks our love is drawn out so subtle already, that 'tis near breaking.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I will have more care of it on my part, than the kindred of an old Pope have to preserve him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Adieu; for this time I wipe off your score.
Till you're caught tripping in some new amour.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: You have us'd me very kindly, Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You deserv'd it for not having a lye ready for my occasions. A good Servant should be no more without it, than a Souldier without his armes. But prethee advise me what's to be done to get Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You have lost her, or will lose her by your submitting: if we men could but learn to value our selves, we should soon take down our Mistresses from all their Altitudes, and make 'em dance after our Pipes, longer perhaps than we had a mind to't.— But I must make haste, or I shall lose Don Melchor.—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Call Bellamy, we'll both be present at thy enterprise: then I'll once more to the Gaming-house with my small stock,
for my last refuge: if I win, I have wherewithall to mollifie Jacinta.
sp.l: If I throw out I'll bear it off with huffing;
And snatch the money like a Bulli-Ruffin.

div.head: ACT. IV.
div.stage: Bellamy, Wildblood: Maskall in a visor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: HEre comes one, and in all probability it must be Don Melchor going to Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Stand close, and you shall see me serve the Writ upon him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Now, Maskall.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I stay'd here, Sir, by express order from the Lady Aurelia, to deliver you this Note; and to desire you from her to meet her immediately in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Do you hear friend!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Not a syllable more, Sir, I have perform'd my orders.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: He's gone; and 'tis in vain for me to look after him. What envious Devil has discover'd to Aurelia that I am in Town? it must be Don Lopez, who to advance his own pretentensions to her, has endeavour'd to ruine mine.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: It works rarely.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But I am resolv'd to see Aurelia; if it be but to defeat him.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let's make haste after him; I long to see the end of this adventure.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.l: Sir, I think I see some women coming yonder.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well; I'll leave you to your adventures; while I prosecute my own.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I warrant you have made an assignation to instruct some Lady in the Mathematicks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'll not tell you my design; because if it does not succeed you shall not laugh at me.
sp.stage: Enter Beatrix; and Jacinta in the habit of a Mulatta.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let us withdraw a little, and see if they will come this way.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: We are right, Madam, 'tis certainly your Englishman, and his Servant with him. But why this second triall, when you engag'd to break with him, if he fail'd in the first?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he has been a little inconstant; cholerick, or so.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And it seems you are not contented with those vices; but are searching him for more. This is the folly of a bleeding Gamester, who will obstinately pursue a losing hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: On t'other side you would have me throw up my Cards before the game be lost: let me make this one more triall, when he has money whether he will give it me, and then if he fails—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You'l forgive him agen.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He's already in Purgatory; but the next offence shall put him in the pit past all redemption; prethee sing to draw him nearer: Sure he cannot know me in this disguise.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Make haste then; for I have more Irons in the fire: when I have done with you I have another assignation of my Lady Theodosia's to Don Melchor.

lg.l: Calm was the Even, and cleer was the Skie,
And the new budding flowers did spring,
When all alone went Amyntas and I
To hear the sweet Nightingale sing;
I sate, and he laid him down by me;
But scarcely his breath he could draw;
For when with a fear he began to draw near,
He was dash'd with A ha ha ha ha!
He blush'd to himself, and lay still for a while,
And his modesty curb'd his desire;
But streight I convinc'd all his fear with a smile,
Which added new flames to his fire.
O Sylvia, said he, you are cruel,
To keep your poor Lover in awe;
Tken once more he prest with his hand to my brest,
But was dash'd with A ha ha ha ha.
I knew 'twas his passion that caus'd all his fear;
And therefore I pity'd his case:
I whisper'd him softly there's no body near,
And layd my cheek close to his face:
But as he grew bolder and bolder,
A Shepherd came by us and saw;
And just as our bliss we began with a kiss,
He laughd out with A ha ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If you dare be the Sylvia, Lady, I have brought you a more confident Amyntas, than that bashful Gentleman in your Song—-
sp.stage: Goes to lay hold of her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, hold; Sir, I am only an Ambassadress sent you from a Lady, I hope you will not violate the Laws of Nations.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I was only searching for your Letters of Credence: but methinks with that beauty you look more like a Herauld that comes to denounce war to all mankind.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: One of the Ladies in the Masque to night has taken a liking to you; and sent you by me this purse of gold, in recompence of that she saw you lose.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And she expects in return of it, that I should wait on her; I'll do't, Where lives she? I am desperately in love with her.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Why, Can you love her unknown?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
I have a Banque of Love, to supply every ones occasions;
some for her, some for another, and some for you; charge what you will upon me, I pay all at sight, and without questioning who brought the Bill.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Heyday, You dispatch your Mistresses as fast, as if you meant to o're-run all Woman-kind: sure you aime at the Universal-Monarchy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now I think on't, I have a foolish fancy to send thy Lady a taste of my love by thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible your love should be so humble, to descend to a Mulatta.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: One would think so, but I cannot help it. Gad, I think the reason is because there's something more of sin in thy colour then in ours. I know not what's the matter, but a Turky-Cock is not more provok'd at red, then I bristle at the sight of black. Come, be kinder to me. Young, and slip an opportunity? 'Tis an Evening lost out of your life.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: These fine things you have said over a thousand times; your cold Compliment's the cold Pye of love which you serve up to every new guest whom you invite.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come; because thou art very moving, here's part of the Gold, which thou brought'st to corrupt me for thy Lady: truth is, I had promis'd a summ to a Spanish Lady— but thy eyes have allur'd it from me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: You'll repent to morrow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let to morrow starve: or provide for himself, as to night has done: to morrow is a cheat in love, and I will not trust it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I, but Heaven that sees all things—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Heaven that sees all things will say nothing: that is, all eyes and no tongue; Et la lune & les estoiles,— you know the Song.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: A poor slave as I am—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It has been alwayes my humour to love downward. I love to stoop to my prey, and to have it in my power to Sowse at when I please. When a man comes to a great Lady, he is fain to approach her with fear and reverence; methinks there's something of Godliness in't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yet I cannot believe, but the meanness of my habit must needs scandalize you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll tell thee my friend and so forth, that I exceedingly honour course Linnen; 'tis as proper sometimes in an under Garment, as a course Towel is to rub and scrub me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Now I am altogether of the other side, I can love no where but above me: methinks the ratling of a Coach and six, sounds more eloquently, then the best Harrangue a Wit could make me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Do you make no more esteem of a Wit then?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: His commendations serve onely to make others have a mind to me; He does but say Grace to me like a Chaplain; and like him is the last that shall fall on. He ought to get no more by it, then a poor Silk-weaver does by the Ribband which he workes, to make a Gallant fine.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: Then what is a Gentleman to hope from you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To be admitted to pass my time with, while a better comes: to be the lowest step in my Stair-case, for a Knight to mount upon him, and a Lord upon him, and a Marquess upon him, and a Duke upon him, till I get as high as I can climb.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For ought I see, the Great Ladies have the Appetites which you Slaves should have; and you Slaves the Pride which ought to be in Ladies. For, I observe, that all women of your condition are like the women of the Play-house, still Piquing at each other, who shall go the best Drest, and in the Richest Habits: till you work up one another by your high flying, as the Heron and Jerfalcon do. If you cannot out-shine your fellow with one Lover, you fetch her up with another: and in short, all you get by it is onely to put Finery out of countenance; and to make the Ladies of Quality go plain, because they will avoid the Scandal of your bravery.

sp.speaker: Beat. running in.
sp.p: Madam, come away; I hear company in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: You are not going?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Yes, to cry out a Rape if you follow me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: However, I am glad you have left your treasure behind you: farewel Fairie.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Farewel Changeling— Come Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Do you know how you came by this money, Sir? you think, I warrant, that it came by fortune.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, Sirrah, I know it came by my own industry. Did not I come out diligently to meet this gold, in the very way it was to come? what could Fate do less for me? they are such thoughtless, and undesigning rogues as you, that make a drudge of poor providence, and set it a shifting for you. Give me a brave fellow like my self; that if you throw him down into the world, lights every where upon his legs, and helps himself without being beholding to Fate, that is the Hospital of fools.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But after all your jollitie, what think you if it was Jacinta that gave it you in this disguise? I am sure I heard her call Beatrix as she went away.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Umh! thou awaken'st a most villainous apprehension in me! methought indeed I knew the voice; but the face was such an evidence against it! if it were so she is lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And so is Beatrix!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Now could I cut my throat for madness.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Now could I break my neck for despair; if I could find a precipice absolutely to my liking.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain to consider on't. There's but one way; go you Maskal, and find her out, and invent some excuse for me, and be sure to beg leave I may come and wait upon her with the gold before she sleeps.

sp.speaker: Mak.
sp.p: In the mean time you'l be thinking at your lodging.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But make haste then to relieve me; for I think over all my thoughts in half an hour.

sp.speaker: Wild solus.
sp.p: Hang't, now I think on't, I shall be but melancholique at my Lodging, I'll go pass my hour at the Gaming-house, and make use of this money while I have tools, to win more to it. Stay, let me see, I have the box and throw. My Don he sets me ten pistols; I nick him: ten more, I sweep them too. Now in all reason he is nettled, and sets me twenty: I win them too. Now he kindles, and butters me with forty. They are all my own: in fine, he is vehement, and bleeds on to fourscore or an hundred; and I not willing to tempt fortune, come away a moderate winner of 200 pistols.
sp.stage: The Scene opens and discovers Aurelia and Camilla: behind them a Table and lights set on it. The Scene is a Garden with an Arbour in it.
sp.p: The Garden dore opens! How now, Aurelia and Camilla in expectation of Don Melchor at the Garden door; I'll away lest I prevent the designe, and within this half hour come sailing back with full pockets, as wantonly as a laden Galleon from the Indies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But dost thou think the Englishman can keep his promise? for I confess I furiously desire to see the Idea of Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: But, Madam, if you should see him, it will not be he, but the Devil in his likeness; and then why should you desire it?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: In effect 'tis a very dark Enigma; and one must be very spiritual to understand it. But be what it will, bodie or fantome, I am resolv'd to meet it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Can you do it without fear?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No; I must avow it, I am furiously fearful; but yet I am resolv'd to sacrifice all things to my love. Therefore let us pass over that chapter.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Do you hear, Madam, there's one treading already; how if it be he?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: If it be he; that is to say his Specter, that is to say his Fantome, that is to say his Idea, that is to say, He and not he.

sp.speaker: Cam. crying out.
sp.p: Ah, Madam, 'tis he himself; but he's as big again as he us'd to be, with eyes like sawcers.— I'll save my self
sp.stage: Enter Don Melchor: they both shreek.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh heaven! humanitie is not able to support it. [running.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Dear Aurelia, what mean you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The Tempter has imitated his voice too; avoid, avoid Specter.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If he should find me under the table now!

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Is it thus my Dear that you treat your Servant?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I am not thy Dear; I renounce thee, spirit of darkness.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This Spirit of darkness is come to see an Angel of light by her command; and to assure her of his constancy, that he will be hers eternally.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Away Infernal, 'tis not thee, 'tis the true Don Melchor that I would see.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hell and Furies.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Heaven and Angels! Ah—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This is a riddle past my finding out, to send for me, and then to shun me; but here's one shall resolve it for me: Camilla, what dost thou there?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Help, help, I shall be carried away, bodily.
sp.stage: She rises up, overthrows the Table and lights, and runs out.

sp.speaker: Mel. alone.
sp.p: Why Aurelia, Camilla! they are both run out of hearing! This amazes me; what can the meaning of it be? Sure she has heard of my unfathfulness, and was resolv'd to punish me by this contrivance! to put an affront upon me by this abrupt departure, as I did on her by my seeming absence.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Don Melchor! is it you my Love that have frighted Aurelia so terribly?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, I know not; but coming hither by your appointment, and thinking my self secure in the night without disguise, perhaps it might work upon her fancie, because she thought me absent.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Since 'tis so unluckily fallen out that she knows you are at Madrid, it can no longer be kept a secret; therefore you must now pretend openly to me, and run the risque of a denial from my Father.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O, Madam, there's no question but he'll refuse me: for alas, what is it he can see in me worthy of that honor? or if he should be so partial to me, as some in the world are, to think me valiant, learned, and not altogether a fool, yet my want of fortune would weigh down all.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: When he has refus'd you his consent, I may with Justice dispose of my self; and that, while you are constant, shall never be to any but your self: in witness of which, accept this Diamond as a Pledge of my hearts firmness to you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Madam, Your Father is coming this way.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; do not stir; since he must know you are return'd, let him now see you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Daughter, What make you here at this unseasonable hour?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir,—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, That you heard a noise, and ran hither to see what it might be— Bless us! Who is this with you?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: 'Tis your servant Don Melchor; just return'd from St. Sebastians.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But, Sir, I thought you had been upon the Sea for Flanders.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I had so design'd it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But, Why came you back from St. Sebastians?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: As for that, Sir, 'tis not material—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: An unexpected Law Sute has call'd him back from St. Sebastians.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And, How fares my Son-in-Law that lives there?

sp.speaker: Melch.
sp.p: In Catholique health, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Have you brought no Letters from him?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I had, Sir, but I was set on by the way, by Pickerons: and, in spight of my resistance, rob'd, and my Portmantue taken from me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: And this was that which he was now desiring me to excuse to you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: If my Credit, Friends, or Counsel can do you any service in your Sute, I hope you will command them freely.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
When I have dispatch'd some private business I shall
not fail to trouble you; till then, humbly kisses your hands, the most oblig'd of your servants—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Daughter, now this Cavalier is gone, What occasion brought you out so late? I know what you would say, That it is Melancholy; a Tincture of the Hypocondriaque you mean: but, What cause have you for this Melancholy? give me your hand, and answer me without Ambages or Ambiguities.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: He will find out I have given away my Ring— I must prevent him— Sir, I am asham'd to confess it to you; but, in hope of your indulgence, I have lost the Table Diamond you gave me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You would say, The fear of my displeasure has caus'd this perturbation in you; well, do not disquiet your self too much, you say 'tis gone; I say so too. 'Tis stollen; and that by some Thief I take it: but, I will go and consult the Astrologer immediately.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What have I done? to avoid one inconvenience, I have run into another: this Devil of an Astrologer will discover that Don Melchor has it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: When did you lose this Diamond? the minute and second I should know; but the hour will serve for the Degree ascending.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, the precise time I know not; but, it was betwixt six and seven this evening, as near as I can guess.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: 'Tis enough; by all the Stars I'll have it for you: Therefore go in, and suppose it on your finger.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I'll watch you at a distance, Sir, that my Englishman may have wherewithall to answer you——

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: This melancholy wherewith my Daughter laboureth, is— a— I know what I would say, is a certain species of the Hysterical Diseases; or a certain motion, caused by a certain appetite, which at a certain time heaveth in her, like a certain motion of an Earthquake—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is the place, and very near the time that Theodosia appoints her meeting with Don Melchor. He is this night otherwise dispos'd of with Aurelia: 'Tis but trying my fortune to tell her of his Infidelity, and my love. If she yields she makes me happy; if not, I shall be sure Don Melchor has not planted the Armes of Spain in the Fort before me. However, I'll push my Fortune as sure as I am an Englishman.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sennor Ingles, I know your voice, though I cannot perfectly discern you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How the Devil come he to cross me?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I was just coming to have ask'd another Favour of you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Without Ceremony command me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My Daughter Theodosia has lost a fair Diamond from her finger, the time betwixt six and seven this evening; now I desire you, Sir, to erect a Scheme for it, and if it be lost, or stollen, to restore it to me— This is all, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is no end of this old Fellow; thus will he baite me from day to day, till my ignorance be found out.—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Now is he casting a Figure by the Art of Memory, and making a Judgment of it to himself. This Astrology is a very mysterious speculation—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis a madness for me to hope I can deceive him longer. Since then he must know I am no Astrologer, I'll discover it my self to him, and blush once for all—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Well, Sir, and what do the Stars hold forth? What sayes nimble Master Mercury to the matter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, not to keep you longer in ignorance, I must ingeniously declare to you that I am not the man for whom you take me. Some smattering in Astrology I have; which my Friends, by their indiscretion, have blown abroad, beyond my intentions. But, you are not a person to be impos'd on like the vulgar: therefore, to satisfie you in one word, my skill goes not farr enough to give you knowledge of what you desire from me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You have said enough, Sir, to perswade me of your Science, if Fame had not publish'd it, yet this very humility of yours were enough to confirm me in the beliefe of it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Death, you make me mad, Sir: Will you have me Swear? As I am a Gentleman, a man of the Town, one who wears good Cloathes, Eates, Drinks, and Wenches abundantly; I am a damn'd ignorant, and senceless Fellow.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: How now Gentlewoman— What, Are you going to reliefe by Moonshine?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I was going on a very charitable Office, to help a Friend that was gravell'd in a very doubtful business.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Some good newes, Fortune, I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: But now I have found this learned Gentleman, I shall make bold to propound a Question to him from a Lady.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I will have my own Question first resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O, Sir, 'tis from a Lady—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: If you please, Sir, I'll tell it in your eare—— My Lady has given Don Melchor the Ring; in whose company her Father found her but just now at the Garden door.

sp.speaker: Bell. aloud.
sp.p: Come to me to morrow, and you shall receive an answer—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir,——

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sir, I shall take it very unkindly if you satisfie any other, and leave me in this perplexity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, if my knowledge were according—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No more of that, Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Perhaps I may know something by my Art concerning it; but, for your quiet, I wish you would not press me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Do you think I am not Master of my Passions?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Since you will needs know what I would willingly have conceal'd, the person who has your Diamond, is he whom you saw last in your Daughters company.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You would say 'tis Don Melchor de Guzman. Who, the Devil would have suspected him of such an action? But he is of a decay'd Family, and poverty it seems has inforc'd him to it: now I think on't better he has e'en stoln it for a fee to bribe his Lawyer; to requite a lye with a theft; I'll seek him out, and tell him part of my mind before I sleep.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So, once more I am at liberty: but this Astrologie is so troublesome a Science— would I were well rid on't.
sp.stage: Enter Don Lopez and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Astrologie does he say? O Cavalier is it you; not finding you at home I came on purpose to seek you out: I have a small request to the Stars by your mediation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, for pity let 'em shine in quiet a little; for what for Ladies and their Servants, and younger Brothers, they scarce get a Holy-day in a twelvemoneth.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, if I am a little curious of my destiny, since all my happiness depends on your answer.

sp.speaker: Bell,
sp.p: Well, Sir, what is it you expect?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: To know whether my love to a Lady will be succesful.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis Aurelia he means— (aside) Sir, in one word I answer you, that your Mistress loves another: one who is your friend: but comfort your self; the Dragons tail is between him and home, he never shall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: But what hope for me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Stars have partly assur'd me you shall be happy, if you acquaint her with your passion, and with the double dealing of your friend, who is false to her.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: You speak like an Oracle. But I have engag'd my promise to that friend to serve him in his passion to my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We English seldom make such scruples; Women are not compris'd in our Laws of friendship: they are ferae naturae; our common game, like Hare and Patridge: every man has equal right to them, as he has to the Sun and Elements.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Must I then betray my friend?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
In that case my friend is a Turk to me, if he will be so barbarous as to retain two women to his private use; I will be
factious for all distressed Damsels; who would much rather have their cause try'd by a full Jury, then a single Judge.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I will take your counsel; and if I erre, the fault be on love and you.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Were it not for love I would run out of the Town, that's the short on't; for I have engag'd my self in so many promises for the Sun and Moon, and those little minc'd-meats of 'em, that I must hide before my day-of-payment comes. In the mean time I forget Theodosia; but now I defie the Devil to hinder me.
sp.stage: As he is going out he meets Aurelia, and almost justles her down. With her Camilla enters.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What rudeness is this?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam Aurelia, is it you?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Monsieur Bellamy!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The same, Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My Unkle told me he left you here: and indeed I came hither to complain of you: for you have treated me so inhumanely that I have some reason to resent it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What occasion can I have given you for a complaint?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Don Melchor, as I am inform'd by my Uncle, is effectively at Madrid: so that it was not his Idea, but himself in person whom I saw: and since you knew this, why did you conceal it from me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: When I spoke with you I knew it not: but I discover'd it in the erecting of my figure. Yet if instead of his Idea I constrain'd himself to come, in spight of his resolution to remain conceal'd, I think I have shown a greater effect of my art then what I promis'd.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I render my self to so convincing an argument: but by over-hearing a discourse just now betwixt my Cousin Theodosia and her Maid, I find that he has conceal'd himself upon her account, which has given me jealousie to the last point; for to avow an incontestable truth, my Cousin is furiously handsome.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Madam, Madam, trust not your ears too far; she talk'd on purpose that you might hear her: but I assure you the true cause of Don Melchor's concealment, was not love of her, but
jealousie of you: he staid in private to observe your actions: build upon't Madam, he is inviolably yours.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Then will he sacrifice my Cousin to me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis furiously true Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O most agreeable assurance!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Albricias Madam, for my good news; Don Melchor is coming this way; I know him by his voice; but he is in company with another person.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: It will not be convenient to give him any umbrage by seeing me with another person; therefore I will go before; do you stay here and conduct him to my Appartment. Good-night Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have promis'd Don Lopez he shall possess her; and I have promis'd her she shall possess Don Melchor: 'tis a little difficult I confess, as to the Matrimonial part of it: but if Don Melchor will be civil to her, and she be civil to Don Lopez, my credit is safe without the benefit of my Clergie. But all this nothing to Theodosia.
sp.stage: Enter Don Alonzo and Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Don Melchor, a word in private.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your pleasure, Lady; Sir, I will wait on you immediately.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I am sent to you from a fair Lady, who bears you no ill will. You may guess whom I mean.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Not by my own merits, but by knowing whom you serve: but I confess I wonder at her late strange usage when she fled from me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: That was only a mistake; but I have now, by her command, been in a thousand places in quest of you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You overjoy me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: And where amongst the rest do you think I have been looking you?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Pray refresh my memory.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: In that same street, by that same shop; you know where by a good token.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By what token?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Just by that shop where, out of your nobleness, you promis'd me a new Silk Gown.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O, now I understand you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Not that I press you to a performance—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Take this, and please your self in the choice of it—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Nay, dear Sir, now you make me blush; in faith I— am asham'd— I swear 'tis only because I would keep something for your sake.— But my Lady expects you immedeiately in her Appartment.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I'll wait on her if I can possibly— Exit Camilla. But if I can prevail with Don Alonzo for his Daughter, then will I again consider, which of the Ladies best deserves me.—
Sir, I beg your pardon for this rudeness in leaving you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I cannot possibly resolve with my self to tell him openly he is a thief; but I'll guild the pill for him to swallow.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I believe he has discover'd our amour: how he surveys me for a Son in law!

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sir, I am sorry for your sake, that true nobility is not alwayes accompanied with riches to support it in it's lustre.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You have a just exception against the Caprichiousness of destiny; yet if I were owner of any noble qualities, (which I am not) I should not much esteem the goods of fortune.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But pray conceive me, Sir, your father did not leave you flourishing in wealth.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Only a very fair Seat in Andalusia, with all the pleasures imaginable about it: that alone, were my poor deserts according, which I confess they are not, were enough to make a woman happy in it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But give me leave to come to the point I beseech you, Sir. I have lost a Jewel which I value infinitely, and I hear it is in your possession: but I accuse your wants, not you, for it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your Daughter is indeed a Jewel, but she were not lost, were she in possession of a man of parts.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: A pretious Diamond Sir.—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But a man of honor, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, Sir, that a man of honor is not capable of an unworthy action; but therefore I do not accuse you of the theft, I suppose the Jewel was only put into your hands.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: By honorable wayes I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, will you restore my Jewel?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Will you please, Sir, to give me leave to be the unworthy possessor of her? I know how to use her with that respect.—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, Sir, but if it belongs to our Family; otherwise I assure you it were at your service.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: As it belongs to your Family I covet it; not that I plead my own deserts, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Sir, I know your deserts; but, I protest I cannot part with it: for, I must tell you, this Diamond Ring was originally my Great Grandfathers.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A Diamond Ring, Sir, do you mean?—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: By your patience, Sir, when I have done you may speak your pleasure. I onely lent it to my Daughter; but, how she lost it, and how it came upon your Finger, I am yet in tenebris.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know it, Sir; but spare your self the trouble, I'll speak for you; you would say you had it from some other hand; I believe it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir, Ile bring you off without your speaking; from another hand you had it; and now Sir, as you say, Sir, and as I am saying for you, Sir, you are loath to part with it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Good Sir,— let me—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I understand you already, Sir, that you have taken a fancy to it, and would buy it; but, to that I answer as I did before, that it is a Relique of my family: now, Sir, if you can urge ought farther, you have liberty to speak without interruption.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: This Diamond you speak on I confess—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But, What need you confess, Sir, before you are accus'd?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You promis'd you would hear me in my turn, Sir, but—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: But, as you were saying, it is needless, because I have already spoken for you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: The truth is, Sir, I was too presumptuous to take this Pledge from Theodosia without your knowledge; but, you will pardon the invincible necessity, when I tell you—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You need not tell me, I know your necessity was the reason of it, and that place and opportunity have caus'd your error.

sp.speaker: Mel.
