sp.p: This is the goodest old man I ever knew; he prevents me in my motion for his Daughter. Since, Sir, you know the cause of my errors, and are pleas'd to lay part of the blame upon Youth and Opportunity; I beseech you favour me so far, to accept me as fair Theodosia already has—.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I conceive you, Sir, that I would accept of your excuse: why restore the Diamond and 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: More joyfully then I receiv'd it: and with it I beg the honour to be receiv'd by you as your Son in Law.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: My Son in Law! this is the most pleasant Proposition I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I am proud you think it so; but, I protest I think not I deserve this honor.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Nor I, I assure you, Sir; marry my daughter— ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: But, Sir—.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, Sir, that there is too much hazard in the Profession of a Thief, and therefore you would Marry my Daughter to become rich, without venturing your Neck for't. I beseech you, Sir, steal on, be apprehended, and if you please, be hang'd, it shall make no breach betwixt us. For my part, I'll keep your Counsel, and so good night, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
Is the Devil in this old man, first to give me occasion to confess my Love, and, when he knew it, to promise he would
keep my Counsel? But, Who are these? I'll not be seen; but to my old appointment with Theodosia, and desire her to unriddle it—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But, Madam, Do you take me for a man of Honour?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Why there's it; if you had, I would have sworn that my Master has neither done nor intended you any injury; I suppose you'll grant he knew you in your disguise?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Nay, to know her, and use her so, is an aggravation of his Crime.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Unconscionable Beatrix! Would you two have all the Carnival to your selves? He knew you, Madam, and was resolv'd to countermine you in all your Plots. But, when he saw you so much piqued, he was too good natur'd to let you sleep in wrath, and sent me to you to disabuse you: for, if the business had gone on till to morrow, when Lent begins, you would have grown so peevish (as all good Catholicks are with fasting) that the quarrel would never have been ended.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well; this mollifies a little: I am content he shall see me.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: But, that you may be sure he knew you, he will bring the Certificate of the Purse along with him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I shall be glad to find him innocent.
sp.stage: Enter Wildblood at the other end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No mortal man ever threw out so often. It could not be me, it must be the Devil that did it: he took all the Chances, and chang'd 'em after I had thrown 'em: but, I'le be even with him; for, I'll never throw one of his Dice more.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis certainly my Master; and he is so zealous to make his peace, that he could not stay till I call'd him to you— Sir.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Sirrah, I'll teach you more manners then to leave me another time: you Rogue, you have lost me two hundred Pistolls, you and the Devil your accomplice; you, by leaving me to myself, and he by tempting me to Play it off.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Is the wind in that door? here's like to be fine doings.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Oh mischiefe! am I fallen into her ambush? I must face it out with another quarrel.—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Your man has been treating your Accommodation; 'tis half made already.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I, On your part it may be.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He sayes you knew me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes; I do know you so well, that my poor heart akes for't: I was going to bed without telling you my mind; but, upon consideration I am come.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To bring the Money with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: To declare my grievances, which are great, and many.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Well, for impudence, let thee alone.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As in the first place—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll hear no Grievances; Where's the Money?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: I; keep to that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do you think me a person to be so us'd?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: We will not quarrel; Where's the Money?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By your favour we will quarrel.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Money, Money—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am angry, and can hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Money, Money, Money, Money.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do you think it a reasonable thing to put on two disguises in a Night, to tempt a man? (Help me, Maskal, for I want Arguments abominably) I thank Heaven I was never so barbarously us'd in all my life.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He begins to anger me in good earnest.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: A thing so much against the Rules of Modesty: so undecent a thing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
I, so undecent a thing: nay, now I do not wonder at my self for being angry. And then to wonder I should love her in those disguises? to quarrel at the natural desires of humane
kind, assaulted by powerful temptations; I am inrag'd at that—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Heyday! you had best quarrel too for my bringing you the Money!

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I have a grudging to you for't: (Maskall, the Money, Maskall; now help or we are gone.)

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Would she offer to bring Money to you? first to affront your poverty——

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I; to affront my poverty. But, that's no great matter; and then—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And then, to bring you Money (I stick fast, Sir.)

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: (Forward, you Dog, and invent, or I'll cut your throat;) and then as I was saying, to bring me Money—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Which is the greatest and most sweet of all temptations; and to think you could resist it: being also aggravated by her handsomeness who brought it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Resist it? no; I would she would understand it, I know better what belongs to flesh and blood then so.

sp.speaker: Beat. to Jac.
sp.p: This is plain confederacie; I smoak it; he came on purpose to quarrel with you; break first with him and prevent it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If it be come to that once, the Devill take the hindmost; I'll not be last in love; for that will be a dishonour to my Sex.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And then—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold Sir; there needs no more: you shall fall out; and I'll gratifie you with a new occasion: I only try'd you in hope you would be false; and rather than fail of my design, brought gold to bribe you to't.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: As people when they have an ill bargain, are content to lose by't, that they may get it off their hands.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Beatrix, while our principals are engag'd, I hold it not for our honor to stand idle.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: With all my heart: please you let us draw off to some other ground.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I dare meet you on any Spot, but one.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
I think we shall do well to put it to an issue; this is
the last time you shall ever be troubled with my addresses.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The favour had been greater to have spar'd this too.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Beatrix, let us dispatch; or they'll break off before us.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Break as fast as thou wilt, I am as brittle as thou art for thy heart.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Because I will absolutely break off with you, I will keep nothing that belongs to you: therefore take back your Picture, and your Handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I have nothing of yours to keep; therefore take back your liberal promises. Take 'em in imagination.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Not to be behind hand with you in your frumps, I give you back your Purse of Gold: take you that— in imagination.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To conclude with you, take back your oathes and protestations; they are never the worse for the wearing I assure you: therefore take 'em, spick and span new, for the use of your next Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Beatrix, follow your leader; here's the sixpenny whittle you gave me, with the Mutton haft: I can spare it, for knives are of little use in Spain.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: There's your Cizars with the stinking brass chain to 'em: 'tis well there was no love betwixt us; for they had been too dull to cut it.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: There's the dandriffe Comb you lent me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: There's your ferret Ribbaning for garters.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I would never have come so near as to have taken 'em from you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For your Letter I have it not about me; but upon reputation I'll burn it.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: And for yours, I have already put it to a fitting imployment.— Courage, Sir; how goes the battel on your wing?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Just drawing off on both sides. Adieu Spain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Farewel old England.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Come away in Triumph; the day's your own Madam.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I'll bear you off upon my shoulders, Sir; we have broke their hearts.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Let her go first then; I'll stay, and keep the honor of the Field.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I'll not retreat, if you stay till midnight.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Are you sure then we have done loving?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes, very sure; I think so.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis well you are so; for otherwise I feel my stomack a little maukish. I should have doubted another sit of love were coming up.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, no; your inconstancy secures you enough for that.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: That's it which makes me fear my own returning: nothing vexes me, but that you should part with me so slightly, as though I were not worth your keeping; well, 'tis a sign you never lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis the least of your care whether I did or did not: it may be it had been more for the quiet of my self, if I— but 'tis no matter, I'll not give you that satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But what's the reason you will not give it me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: For the reason that we are quite broke off.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why are we quite broke off?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why are we not?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, since 'tis past, 'tis past; but a pox of all foolish quarrelling for my part.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And a mischief of all foolish disguisements for my part.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But if it were to do again with another Mistress, I would e'en plainly confess I had lost my money.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And if I had to deal with another Servant, I would learn more wit then to tempt him in disguises: for that's to throw a Venice-glass to the ground, to try if it would not break.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If it were not to please you, I see no necessity of our parting.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I protest I do it only out of complaisance to you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But if I should play the fool and ask you pardon, you would refuse it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, never submit, for I should spoil you again with pardoning you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
Do you hear this, Beatrix? they are just upon the
point of accommodation; we must make haste or they'll make a peace by themselves; and exclude us from the Treaty.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Declare your self the Aggressor then; and I'll take you into mercy.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The worst that you can say of me is that I have lov'd you thrice over.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The prime Articles between Spain and England are seal'd; for the rest concerning a more strict alliance; if you please we'll dispute them in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But in the first place let us agree on the Article of Navigation I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: These Leagues offensive and defensive will be too strict for us, Maskall: a Treaty of commerce will serve our turn.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: With all my heart; and when our loves are veering, We'll make no words, but fall to privateering.
sp.stage: Exeunt, the men leading the women.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: TIs true, if he had continu'd constant to you, I should have thought my self oblig'd in honor to be his friend; but I could no longer suffer him to abuse a person of your worth and beauty with a feign'd affection.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But is it possible Don Melchor should be false to love? I'll be sworn I did not imagine such a treacherie could have been in nature; especially to a Lady who had so oblig'd him.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: 'Twas this, Madam, which gave me the coufidence to wait upon at an hour which would be otherwise unseasonable.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You are the most obliging person in the world.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: But to clear it to you that he is false; he is at this very minute at an assignation with your Cousin in the Garden; I am sure he was endeavouring it not an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I swear this Evenings Air begins to incommode me extremely with a cold; but yet in hope of detecting this perjur'd man I am content to stay abroad.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: But withall you must permit me tell you, Madam, that it is but just I should have some share in a heart which I endeavour to redeem: in the Law of Arms you know that they who pay the ransome have right to dispose of the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The prize is so very inconsiderable that 'tis not worth the claiming.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: If I thought the boon were small, I would not importune my Princess with the asking it: but since my life depends upon the grant—

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Mam, I must needs tell your Laship that Don Lopez has deserv'd you: for he has acted all along like a Cavalier; and more for your interest than his own; besides Mam Don Melchor is as poor as he is false: for my part I shall ne're endure to call him Master.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Don Lopez go along with me, I can promise nothing, but I swear I will do my best to disingage my heart from this furious tender which I have for him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: If I had been a man I could never have forsaken you: Ah those languishing casts, Mam; and that pouting lip of your Laship, like a Cherry-bough weigh'd down with the weight of fruit.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And that sigh too I think is not altogether disagreeaable: but something charmante and mignonne.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Well, Don Lopez, you'l be but too happy.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: If I were once possessor—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: O we are surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, I think I know 'em: Don Lopez?

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Our famous Astrologer, how come you here!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am infinitely happy to have met you with Donna Aurelia, that you may do me the favour to satisfie this Lady of a truth which I can scarce perswade her to believe.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p:
I am glad our concernments are so equal: for I have
the like favour to ask from Donna Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Don Lopez is too noble to be refus'd any thing within my power; and I am ready to do him any service after I have ask'd my Cousin if ever Don Melchor pretended to her?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis the very question which I was furiously resolv'd to have ask'd of you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I must confess he has made some professions to me: and withall I will acknowledge my own weakness so far as to tell you I have given way he should often visit me when the world believ'd him absent.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: O Cavalier Astrologer; how have you betrayd me! did you not assure me that Don Melchor's tender and inclination was for me only?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I had it from his Star, Madam, I do assure you, and if that twinkled false, I cannot help it: The truth is there's no trusting the Planet of an inconstant man: his was moving to you when I look'd on't, and if since it has chang'd the course, I am not to be blam'd for't.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Now, Madam, the truth is evident. And for this Cavalier he might easily be deceiv'd in Melchor, for I dare affirm it to you both, he never knew to which of you he was most inclin'd: for he visited one, and writ letters to the other.

sp.speaker: Bell. to Theo.
sp.p: Then Madam I must claim your promise: (since I have discover'd to you that Don Melchor is unworthy of your favours) that you would make me happy, who amongst my many imperfections can never be guilty of such a falsehood.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: If I have been deceiv'd in Melchor whom I have known so long, you cannot reasonably expect I should trust you at a dayes acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For that, Madam, you may know as much of me in a day as you can in all your life: all my humours circulate like my blood, at farthest within 24 hours. I am plain and true like all my Countrymen; you see to the bottom of me as easily as you do to the gravel of a clear stream in Autumn.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: You plead so well, Sir, that I desire you would speak for me too: my cause is the same with yours, only it has not so good an Advocate.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Since I cannot make my self happy, I will have the glory
to felicitate another: and therefore I declare I will reward the fidelity of Don Lopez.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: All that I can say at present is, that I will never be Don Melchors: the rest time and your service must make out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have all I can expect, to be admitted as eldest Servant; as preferment falls I hope you will remember my seniority.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Mam, Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Cavaliers retire a little; we shall see to which of us he will make his Court.

sp.speaker: Don Melchor
sp.p: I thought you had been a bed before this time.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Fair Aurelia, this is a blessing beyond expectation to see you agen so soon.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What important business brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Onely to make my peace with you before I slept. You know you are the Saint to whom I pay my devotions.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And yet it was beyond your expectances to meet me? This is furiously incongruous.

sp.speaker: Theo. advancing.
sp.p: Don Melchor, whither were you bound so late?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What shall I say? I am so confounded that I know not to which of them I should excuse my self.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Pray answer me truly to one question: did you never make any addresses to my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Madam, there's a question indeed.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: How Monster of ingratitude, can you deny the Declaration of your passion to me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I say nothing Madam.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Which of us is it for whom you are concern'd?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: For that Madam, you must excuse me; I have more discretion then to boast a Ladies favour.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Did you counterfeit an address to me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Still I say nothing, Madam; but I will satisfie either of you in private; for these matters are too tender for publick discourse.
sp.stage: Enter Lopez and Bellamy hastily with their swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Bellamy and Lopez!
sp.p: This is strange!

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Ladies, we would not have disturb'd you, but as we were walking to the Garden door, it open'd suddenly against us, and we confusedly saw by Moon-light, some persons entring, but who they were we know not.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You had best retire into the Garden-house, and leave us to take our fortunes, without prejudice to your reputations.

sp.speaker: Wild. to Jacinta entring.
sp.p: Do not fear, Madam, I think I heard my friends voice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Marry hang you, is it you that have given us this hot alarme.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: There's more in't than you imagine, the whole house is up: for seeing you two, and not knowing you after I had entred the Garden-door, I made too much haste to get out again, and have left the key broken in it. With the noise one of the Servants came runing in, whom I forc'd back; and doubtless he is gone for company, for you may see lights running through every Chamber.

sp.speaker: Theo. Jaci.
sp.p: What will become of. us?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We must have recourse to our former resolution. Let the Ladies retire into the Garden-house. And now I think on't you Gentlemen shall go in with 'em, and leave me and Maskall to bear the brunt on't.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Me, Sir? I beseech you let me go in with the Ladies too; dear Beatrix speak a good word for me, I protest 'tis more out of love to thy company than for any fear I have.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You Dog I have need of your wit and counsel. We have no time to deliberate. Will you stay, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis not for my safety.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Will you in Sir?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p:
No Sir, 'tis not for my honor, to be assisting to you:
I'll to Don Alonzo, and help to revenge the injury you are doing him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Then we are lost, I can do nothing.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, and you talk of honor, by your leave Sir. I hate your Spanish honor ever since it spoyl'd our English Playes, with faces about and t'other side.
sp.stage: Falls upon him & throws him down.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: What do you mean, you will not murder me?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Must valour be oppress'd by multitudes?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come yarely my mates, every man to his share of the burthen. Come yarly hay.
sp.stage: The four men take him each by a limb, and carry him out, he crying murder.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: If this Englishman save us now I shall admire his wit.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Good wits never think themselves admir'd till they are well rewarded: you must pay him in specie, Madam, give him love for his wit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ladies fear nothing, but enter into the Garden-house with these Cavaliers—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Oh that I were a Cavalier too!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come you back Sirrah.
Think your selves as safe as in a Sanctuary, only keep quiet what ever happens.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Come away then, they are upon us.
sp.stage: Exeunt all but Bell. and Mask.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Hark, I hear the foe coming: methinks they threaten too, Sir; pray let me go in for a Guard to the Ladies and poor Beatrix. I can fight much better when there is a wall betwixt me and danger.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Peace, I have occasion for your wit to help me lie.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Sir, upon the faith of a sinner you have had my last lye already; I have not one more to do me credit as I hope to be sav'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Victore, victore; knock under you rogue, and confess me Conquerour, and you shall see I'll bring all off.
sp.stage: Enter Don Alonzo and six Servants; with lights and swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Search about there.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fear nothing, do but vouch what I shall say.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: For a passive lye I can yet do something.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Stand: who goes there?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Friends.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Friends? who are you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Noble Don Alonzo, such as are watching for your good.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Is it you, Sennor Ingles? why all this noise and tumult? where are my Daughters and my Neece? But in the first place, though last nam'd, how came you hither, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I came hither— by Astrologie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: My Master's in, heavens send him good shipping with his lye, and all kind Devils stand his friends.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: How, by Astrologie, Sir? meaning you came hither by Art Magick.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I say by pure Astrologie Sir, I foresaw by my Art a little after I had left you that your Neece and Daughters would this night run a risque of being carried away from this very Garden.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: O the wonders of this speculation!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thereupon I call'd immediately for my sword and came in all haste to advertise you; but I see there's no resisting Destiny, for just as I was entring the Garden door I met the Women with their Gallants all under sail and outward bound.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Thereupon what does me he but draws by my advice—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now Mr. Raskall? are you itching to be in?

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me go snip with you in this lye, and be not too covetous of honor? you know I never stood with you; now my courage is come to me I cannot resist the temptation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Content; tell on.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p:
So in short Sir we drew, first I, and then my Master; but, being overpower'd, they have escap'd us, so that I think
you may go to bed and trouble your self no further, for gone they are.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You tell a lye! you have curtail'd my invention: you are not fit to invent a lye for a Bawd when she would whedle a young Squire.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Call up the Officers of Justice, I'll have the Town search'd immediately.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain, Sir; I know by my Art you'll never recover 'em: besides, 'tis an affront to my friends the Stars, who have otherwise dispos'd of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the key is broken in the Garden-door, and the door lock'd, so that of necessitie they must be in the Garden yet.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Disperse your selves, some into the Wilderness, some into the Allyes, and some into the Parterre: you Diego, go trie to get out the key, and run to the Corigidore for his assistance: in the mean time I'll search the Garden-house my self.
sp.stage: Exeunt all the Servants but one.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I'll be unbetted again if you please Sir, and leave you all the honor of it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Come Cavalier, let us in together.

sp.speaker: Bell. holding him.
sp.p: Hold Sir for the love of heaven, you are not mad.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: We must leave no place unsearch'd. A light there.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold I say, do you know what you are undertaking? and have you arm'd your self with resolution for such an adventure?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What adventure?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: A word in private— The place you would go into is full of enchantments; there are at this time, for ought I know, a Legion of spirits in it.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You confound me with wonder, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
I have been making there my Magical operations, to know the event of your Daughters flight: and, to perform it rightly, have been forc'd to call up Spirits of several Orders: and there they are humming like a swarm of Bees, some stalking
about upon the ground, some flying, and some sticking upon the walls like Rear-mice.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: The Devil's in him, he's got off again.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Now Sir I shall trie the truth of your friendship to me. To confess the secret of my soul to you, I have all my life been curious to see a Devil: And to that purpose have con'd Agrippa through and through, and made experiment of all his rules, Pari die & incremento Lunae, and yet could never compass the sight of one of these Daemoniums: if you will ever oblige me let it be on this occasion.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: There's another storm arising.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall pardon me, Sir, I'll not expose you to that perril for the world without due preparations of ceremony.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: For that, Sir, I alwayes carry a Talisman about me; that will secure me: and therefore I will venture in a Gods name, and desie 'em all at once.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: How the pox will he get off from this?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since you are so resolv'd, send off your Servant that there may be no noise made on't, and we'll take our venture.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Pedro, leave your light, and help the fellows search the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: What does my incomprehensible Master mean?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now I must tell you Sir, you will see that which will very much astonish you if my Art fail me not.
You Spirits and Intelligences that are within there, stand close, and silent, at your perril, and fear nothing, but appear in your own shapes, boldly.— Maskal open the door.
sp.stage: Maskall goes to one side of the Scene, which draws, and discovers Theo. Jac. Aur. Beat. Cam. Lop. Wild. standing all without motion in a rank.
sp.p: Now Sir what think you?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: They are here, they are here: we need search no farther. Ah you ungratious baggages!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stay, or you'll be torn in pieces: these are the very shapes I Conjur'd up, and truly represent to you in what company your Niece and Daughters are, this very moment.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Why are they not they? I durst have sworn that some of 'em had been my own flesh and blood— Look; one of them is just like that rogue your Camrade.
sp.stage: Wildblood shakes his head and frowns at him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you see how you have provok'd that English Devil: take heed of him; if he gets you once into his clutches:—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: He seems to have got possession of the Spirit of my Jacinta by his hugging her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, I imagin'd as much: do but look upon his physiognomy, you have read Baptista Porta: has he not the leer of a very lewd debauch'd Spirit?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: He has indeed: Then there's my Neece Aurelia, with the Spirit of Don Lopez; but that's well enough; and my Daughter Theodosia all alone: pray how comes that about?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She's provided for with a Familiar too: one that is in this very room with you, and by your Elbow; but I'll shew you him some other time.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And that Baggage Beatrix, how I would swinge her if I had her here; I lay my life she was in the Plot for the flight of her Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir you do ill to provoke her: for being the Spirit of a Woman, she is naturally mischievous: you see she can scarce hold her hands from you already.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Let me alone to revenge your quarrel upon Beatrix: if e're she come to light I'll take a course with her I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now come away Sir, you have seen enough: the Spirits are in pain whilst we are here: we keep 'em too long condens'd in bodies: if we were gone they would rarifie into air immediately. Maskall shut the door.
sp.stage: Maskall goes to the Scene and it closes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Monstrum hominis! O prodigie of Science!
sp.stage: Enter two Servants with Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Now help me with a lye Maskall, or we are lost.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Sir, I could never lie with man or woman in a fright.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, we found this Gentleman bound and gagg'd, and he desir'd us to bring him to you with all haste imaginable.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: O Sir, Sir, your two Daughters and your Niece—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: They are gone he knows it: but are you mad Sir to set this pernicious wretch at libertie?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I endeavour'd all that I was able—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: Now Sir I have it for you— Aside to his Master. He was endeavouring indeed to have got away with 'em: for your Daughter Theodosia was his prize: but we prevented him, and left him in the condition in which you see him.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I thought somewhat was the matter that Theodosia had not a Spirit by her, as her Sister had.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This was he I meant to shew you.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Do you believe him Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, no, believe him Sir: you know his truth ever since he stole your Daughters Diamond.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I swear to you by my honor.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Nay, a thief I knew him, and yet after that, he had the impudence to ask me for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Was he so impudent? The case is plain Sir, put him quickly into custody.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Hear me but one word Sir, and I'll discover all to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hear him not Sir: for my Art assures me if he speaks one syllable more, he will cause great mischief.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Will he so? I'll stop my ears, away with him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Your Daughters are yet in the Garden, hidden by this fellow and his accomplices.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.stage: at the same time drowning him.
sp.l: I'll stop my ears, I'll stop my ears.

sp.speaker: Bell. and Mask.
sp.l: A thief, a thief, away with him.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: He thought to have born us down with his confidence.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, with much ado we have got out the key and open'd the door.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Then, as I told you, run quickly to the Corigidor, and desire him to come hither in person to examine a malefactor.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Hark, what noise is that within? I think one sneezes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One of the Devils I warrant you has got a cold with being so long out of the fire.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Bless his Devilship as I may say.

sp.speaker: Ser. to Don Alonzo.
sp.p: This is a mans voice, do not suffer your self to be deceiv'd so grosly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: A mans voice, that's a good one indeed! that you should live to these years and yet be so silly as not to know a man from a Devil.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: There's more in't than I imagin'd: hold up your Torch and go in first, Pedro, and I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: No let me have the honor to be your Usher.
sp.stage: Takes the Torch and goes in.

sp.speaker: Mask. within.
sp.p: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Stir not upon your life Sir.
sp.stage: Enter Maskall again without the Torch.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I was no sooner entred, but a huge Giant seiz'd my Torch, and fell'd me along, with the very whiffe of his breath as he past by me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Bless us!

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.stage: at the door to them within.
sp.p: Pass out now while you have time in the dark: the Officers of Justice will be here immediately, the Garden-door is open for you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: What are you muttering there Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Only dismissing these Spirits of darkness, that they may trouble you no further: go out I say.
sp.stage: They all come out upon the Stage, groaping their way. Wildblood falls into Alonzo's hands.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I have caught some body; are these your Spirits? Another light quickly, Pedro.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: 'Tis Maskall you have caught, Sir; do you mean to strangle me that you press me so hard between your Arms?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Is it thee Maskall? I durst have sworn it had been another.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Make haste now before the Candle comes.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Now I have another.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Tis Maskall you have caught Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No I thank you Niece, this artifice is too gross! I know your voice a little better. What ho bring lights there.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Her impertinence has ruin'd all.
sp.stage: Enter Servants with lights and swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, the Corigidor is coming according to your desire: in the mean time we have secur'd the Garden doors.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I am glad on't: I'll make some of 'em severe examples.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay then as we have liv'd merrily, so let us die together: but we'll shew the Don some sport first.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What will become of us!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: We'll die for company: nothing vexes me but that I am not a man to have one thrust at that malicious old father of mine before I go.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Let us break our way through the Corigidor's band.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A match i'faith: we'll venture our bodies with you: you shall put the baggage in the middle.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: He that pierces thee, I say no more, but I shall be somewhat angry with him: [to Alonzo] in the mean time I arrest you Sir, in the behalf of this good company. As the Corigidor uses us, so we'll use you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: You do not mean to murder me!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You murder your self if you force us to it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Give me a Razor there, that I may scrape his weeson, that the bristles may not hinder me when I come to cut it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What need you bring matters to that extremity? you have your ransome in your hand: here are three men, and there are three women; you understand me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If not, here's a sword and there's a throat: you understand me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: This is very hard!

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: The propositions are good, and marriage is as honorable as it us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: You had best let your Daughters live branded with the name of Strumpets: for what ever befalls the men, that will be sure to be their share.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I can put them into a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: All the Women.
sp.p: A Nunnery!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I would have thee to know, thou graceless old man, that I defie a Nunnery: name a Nunnery once more, and I disown thee for my Father.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: You know the Custome of the Country, in this case Sir: 'tis either death or marriage: the business will certainly be publick; and if they die they have sworn you shall bear 'em company.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Since it must be so, run Pedro and stop the Corigidor: tell him it was only a Carnival merriment, which I mistook for a Rape and Robbery.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Why now you are a dutiful Father again, and I receive you into grace.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Among the rest of your mistakes, Sir, I must desire you to let my Astrologie pass for one: my Mathematicks, and Art Magick were only a Carnival device; and now that's ending, I have more mind to deal with the flesh than with the devil.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: No Astrologer! 'tis impossible!

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I have known him, Sir, this seven years, and dare take my oath he has been alwayes an utter stranger to the Stars: and indeed to any thing that belongs to heaven.

sp.speaker: Lop.
sp.p: Then I have been cozen'd among the rest.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: And I; but I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p:
I hope you will forgive me, Madam; who have been
the cause on't; but what he wants in Astrologie he shall make up to you some other way I'll pass my word for him.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I hope you are both Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As good as the Cid himself, Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: And for your Religion, right Romanes—

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As ever was Marc Anthony.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: For your fortunes and courages—

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: They are both desperate, Sir; especially their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Theo. to Bell.
sp.p: You should not have had my consent so soon, but only to revenge my self upon the falseness of Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I must avow that gratitude, for Don Lopez is as prevalent with me as revenge against Don Melchor.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Lent you know begins to morrow; when that's over marriage will be proper.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: If I stay till after Lent, I shall be to marry when I have no love left: I'll not bate you an Ace of to night, Father: I mean to bury this man e're Lent be done, and get me another before Easter.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: Well, make a night on't then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Jacinta Wildblood, welcome to me: since our Starres have doom'd it so we cannot help it: but 'twas a meer trick of Fate to catch us thus at unawares: to draw us in with a what do you lack as we pass'd by: had we once separated to night, we should have had more wit than ever to have met again to morrow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: 'Tis true we shot each other flying: we were both upon wing I find; and had we pass'd this Critical minute, I should have gone for the Indies, and you for Greenland e're we had met in a bed upon consideration.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You have quarrell'd twice to night without bloodshed, 'ware the third time.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: A propos! I have been retrieving an old Song of a Lover that was ever quarrelling with his Mistress: I think it will fit our amour so well, that if you please I'll give it you for an Epithalamium: and you shall sing it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I never sung in all my life; nor ever durst trie when I was alone, for fear of braying.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Just me, up and down; but for a frolick let's sing together: for I am sure if we cannot sing now, we shall never have cause when we are married.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Begin then; give me my Key, and I'll set my voice to't.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Fa la, fa la, fa la.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Fala, fala, fala. Is this your best upon the faith of a Virgin?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I by the Muses, I am at my pitch.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Then do your worst: and let the company be judge who sings worst.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Upon condition the best singer shall wear the breeches: prepare to strip Sir; I shall put you into your drawers presently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I shall be reveng'd with putting you into your smock anon; St. George for me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: St. James for me: come start Sir.

lg.head: Damon.
lg.l: Celimena, of my heart,
None shall e're bereave you:
If, with your good leave, I may
Quarrel with you once a day,
I will never leave you.

lg.head: 2. Celimena.
lg.l: Passion's but an empty name
Where respect is wanting:
Damon you mistake your ayme;
Hang your heart, and burn your flame,
If you must be ranting.

lg.head: 3. Damon.
lg.l: Love as dull and muddy is,
As decaying liquor:
Anger sets it on the lees,
And refines it by degrees,
Till it workes it quicker.

lg.head: 4. Celimena.
lg.l: Love by quarrels to beget
Wisely you endeavour;
With a grave Physician's wit
Who to cure an Ague fit
Put me in a Feavor.

lg.head: 5. Damon.
lg.l: Anger rouzes love to fight,
And his only bayt is,
'Tis the spurre to dull delight,
And is but an eager bite,
When desire at height is.

lg.head: 6. Celimena.
lg.l: If such drops of heat can fall
In our wooing weather;
If such drops of heat can fall,
We shall have the Devil and all
When we come together.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your judgement Gentlemen: a Man or a Maid?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And you make no better harmony after you are married then you have before, you are the miserablest couple in Christendome.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: 'Tis no great matter; if I had had a good voice she would have spoil'd it before tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: When Maskall has married Beatrix, you may learn of her.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: You shall put her life into a Lease then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Upon condition that when I drop into your house from hunting, I may set my slippers at your door, as a Turk does at a Jews, that you may not enter.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: And while you refresh your self within, he shall wind the horn without.

sp.speaker: Mask.
sp.p: I'll throw up my Lease first.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why thou would'st not be so impudent, to marry Beatrix: for thy self only?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: For all his ranting and tearing now, I'll pass my word he shall degenerate into as tame and peaceable a Husband as a civil Woman would wish to have.
sp.stage: Enter Don Melchor with a Servant.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.p: I know what you would say, but your discoverie comes too late now.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Why the Ladies are found.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But their inclinations are lost I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Look you Sir, there goes the game: your Plate-fleet is divided; half for Spain, and half for England.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You are justly punish'd for loving two.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Yet I have the comfort of a cast Lover: I will think well of my self; and despise my Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Enough, enough; let's end the Carnival abed.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And for these Gentlemen, when e're they try, May they all speed as soon, and well as I.

lg.l: MY part being small, I have had time to day.
To mark your various censures of our Play:
First, looking for a Judgement or a Wit,
Like Jews I saw 'em scatter'd through the Pit:
And where a knot of Smilers lent an eare
To one that talk'd, I knew the foe was there.
The Club of jests went round; he who had none
Borrow'd oth' next, and told it for his own:
Among the rest they kept a fearfull stir,
In whisp'ring that he stole th' Astrologer;
And said, betwixt a French and English Plot
He eas'd his half-tir'd Muse, on pace and trot.
Up starts a Monsieur new come o're; and warm
In the French stoop; and the pull-back oth' arm;
Morbleu dit il, and cocks, I am a rogue
But he has quite spoil'd the feint Astrologue.
Pox, sayes another; here's so great a stir
With a son of a whore Farce that's regular,
A rule where nothing must decorum shock!
Dam' me 'tis as dull as dining by the clock.
An Evening! why the devil should we be vext
Whither he gets the Wench this night or next?
When I heard this, I to the Poet went,
Told him the house was full of discontent,
And ask'd him what excuse he could invent.
He neither swore nor storm'd as Poets do,
But, most unlike an Author, vow'd 'twas true.
Yet said, he us'd the French like Enemies,
And did not steal their Plots, but made 'em prize.
But should he all the pains and charges count
Of taking 'em, the bill so high wou'd mount,
That, like Prize-goods, which through the Office come,
He could have had 'em much more cheap at home.
He still must write; and Banquier-like, each day
Accept new Bills, and he must break, or pay.
When through his hands such sums must yearly run,
You cannot think the Stock is all his own.
His haste his other errors might excuse;
But there's no mercy for a guilty Muse:
For like a Mistress, she must stand or fall,
And please you to a height, or not at all.
